thread.title: Jays have history (and maybe the weather) on their side in Texas series
thread.title_full: Jays have history (and maybe the weather) on their side in Texas series | Toronto Star

author: Peter Edwards
title: Jays have history (and maybe the weather) on their side in Texas series
text:
Feeling a bit blue, Blue Jays fans?
Perhaps you can buoy your spirits with thoughts of Hall of Fame pitcher Charles Herbert (Red) Ruffing .
Yes, the Jays have lost four of their final five regular season games and yes, that unseemly skid means they face the American League West champion Texas Rangers in a best-of-give series starting Thursday at the Rogers Centre.
Also yes, the late-season ugliness might have been avoided if the Jays started their No. 1 starter, left-hander David Price, in any of those final regular season games.
That said, Price will have 11 days rest when he takes the mound on Thursday.
That leads us to seeking comfort in the memory of Ruffing.
Ruffing was the last major league pitcher to start a playoff game with 11 days rest.
He did this back on Oct. 4, 1939 when he played for the New York Yankees in the opening World Series game against the Cincinnati Reds.
Ruffing was stellar that day, giving up just four hits in a 2-1 complete game win, when Bill Dickie drove home Joe DiMaggio in the 9th.
The Yankees went on to sweep that series.
There are more recent reasons for Jays fans to consider strutting again.
The Jays still enjoy up to three home games in the best-of-5 series against Texas and the Rangers haven’t been happy campers at the Rogers Centre.
The Rangers have been 7-17 there since 2009, including a 2-4 record this year.
Perhaps the thought of sunny skies will perk you up even more.
The Jays seem particularly productive with the roof of the Rogers Centre open.
They don’t get to make that decision. During the postseason, such decisions are made by Major League Baseball.
There’s a 20 per cent chance of precipitation for Game 1 on Thursday and a 30 per cent chance for Friday’s Game 2 at Roger’s Centre.
This season, the Jays are 38-14 with the roof open.
For whatever reason, Jays batters tend to smack the ball further when they can see the open skies and enjoy a 91-49 edge this season in homers when the Rogers’ lid is open.
That said, there are still things to worry about, if you are the worrying sort.
Price might be a candidate for the Cy Young award but he isn’t always at his best against the Rangers.
His overall career record against them is 3-7 with a 5.04 ERA, although he gave up just two runs in six innings in a 12-4 win in his only start against them this season.
The Rangers also added star hurler Cole Hamels at mid-season and Star baseball columnist Richard Griffin notes that their right-hander Yovani Gallardo hasn’t allowed a run in 13.2 innings.
